children.name: to show that sth is correct or true
prove
children.definition: to show that something is definitely true, by providing facts or information:
examples: chứng minh, chứng tỏ
▪ We’re sure Jason took the money, but we can’t prove it.
▪ Until there is evidence to prove any of these claims, we cannot pass judgement.
prove that
chứng minh rằng
▪ Can you prove that you were at home at the time of the attack?
▪ He wanted to prove that he was just as clever as his sister.
prove somebody wrong/innocent/guilty
chứng minh ai đó sai/vô tội/có tội
▪ I would love to prove him wrong.
prove something to somebody
chứng minh một cái gì đó đối với ai đó
▪ I’m telling the truth, and I can prove it to you.
prove where/how etc
chứng minh ở nơi nào/ như thế nào vv
▪ Don’t trust anyone who turns up at your door, unless they can prove who they are.
prove something conclusively/beyond doubt : thuyết phục
▪ His guilt has never been conclusively proven.

children.name: show
children.definition: iffactsoractionsshow that something is true, they prove that it is true:
examples: chứng tỏ, cho thấy, hiển thị
▪ The Prime Minister’s comments show his ignorance of people’s feelings.
show (that)
cho thấy rằng
▪ Research shows that smiling increases the levels of hormones that promote good health.
show where/how etc
hiển thị ở đâu/như thế nào vv
▪ These figures show how serious the company’s problems are.
show something/somebody to be something
hiển thị một cái gì đó / ai đó để là cái gì
▪ A scientific theory is only ‘true’ until someone shows it to be false or inaccurate.

children.name: demonstrate
children.definition: to do something or provide information which makes it very clear to people that something is true:
examples: chứng minh, giải thích
▪ The studies demonstrate a clear link between smoking and heart disease.
demonstrate (that)
giải thích rằng
▪ The President is anxious to demonstrate that he has a strong foreign policy.
demonstrate where/how etc
giải thích ở đâu/như thế nào vv
▪ Try to round off your answer by demonstrating how your old job has prepared you to do the job you are applying for.

children.name: confirm
children.definition: if apiece of new informationconfirms an idea or belief that people already have, it shows that it is definitely true:
examples: chứng thực, củng cố
▪ Police have found new evidence that confirms his story.
confirm that
xác nhận là
▪ The discovery seems to confirm that people lived here over 10,000 years ago.
confirm somebody’s worst fearsprove that something is as bad as someone thought it was: chứng thực nỗi lo sợ nhất của ai
▪ In July his worst fears were confirmed: he had cancer.

children.name: support
examples: sự ủng hộ
support a theory/claim/notion/ view etc
hỗ trợ một lý thuyết / tuyên bố / khái niệm / xem vv
to help to prove that a belief, idea etc is probably true:
▪ Do you have any evidence to support these claims?
▪ The notion that women are worse drivers than men is simply not supported by the facts.
▪ For twenty-five years he painstakingly amassed evidence to support his hypothesis.

children.name: back up
children.definition: to provide additional information to help prove that a statement, belief, or explanation is correct:
examples: hỗ trợ, sao lưu
back up something
sao lưu cái gì đó
▪ When you write a history essay, you should back up all your points with facts.
back something/it/them up
hỗ trợ cái gì đó/nó/họ
▪ They claim they can give us the best deal, but can they back this up with guarantees?
▪ Wright was accused of pretending to be injured, and this was backed up by video evidence.

children.name: bear out
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive phrasal verb not usually in progressive]
children.definition: if facts or information bear out a claim or opinion, they support it and help to prove that it is probably true:
examples: xác nhận
bear out something
xác nhận một cái gì đó
▪ Most of the available evidence bears out the view that students learn better in small classes than in large classes.
▪ My warnings about Jean-Paul were later borne out by his dishonesty.
bear somebody out
chịu đựng ai đó
prove what someone has said is true
▪ Last summer I predicted an increase in terrorist violence, and recent events have borne me out.

children.name: substantiate
children.definition: to provide additional information that helps to prove that a statement is correct, especially if the statement is difficult to believe:
examples: chứng minh
substantiate a claim/an allegation
chứng minh một cáo buộc/một yêu cầu bồi thường
▪ The authorities claimed they were conspiring to overthrow the government, but offered no evidence to substantiate these claims.
▪ Allegations made by prisoners are usually only considered when substantiated by the evidence of a prison officer.

children.name: validate
children.definition: to prove that information or results are correct by using scientific tests or very careful checking - used in scientific or technical contexts:

children.name: làm cho có giá trị, làm cho có hiệu lực, làm cho hợp lệ; phê chuẩn
examples: ▪ All the information used in this report has been validated by an independent panel of experts.
▪ This is an interesting hypothesis, but all attempts to validate it have so far failed.

children.name: corroborate
children.definition: to provide additional information which supports or agrees with something that most people already accept as true - used in scientific and legal contexts:
examples: làm chứng, chứng thực; làm vững thêm (lý lẽ, ý kiến...)
▪ Levine claims that a third car was involved in the accident and witnesses have corroborated this.
▪ Professor Carling’s findings have been corroborated by more recent research.
corroborate a story
làm chứng một câu chuyện
▪ There was no one to corroborate her story about the disturbance in the lounge.
corroborating evidence
xác nhận bằng chứng
▪ No doctor would order surgery on the basis of a single test result, without corroborating clinical evidence.

children.name: to prove that sth is wrong, untrue, or does not exist
disprove
children.definition: to prove that something is wrong or not true: bác bỏ
examples: ▪ She was able to produce figures that disproved Smith’s argument.
▪ The existence of God is a question of faith, and therefore impossible to prove or disprove.

children.name: refute
children.definition: to prove that what someone has said is not true:

children.name: bác bỏ, bẻ lại
examples: ▪ I knew that he was lying but I had no evidence with which to refute his story.
▪ The accusation has been wholly refuted by an in-depth analysis of the evidence.

children.name: debunk
children.definition: to prove that something is not true, especially something that people have believed for a long time, and make it seem silly or unimportant:

children.name: lật tẩy
examples: ▪ In her book she debunks a lot of the claims made by astrologers.
▪ Payton wants to debunk the myth that economics is a science.

children.name: invalidate
children.definition: if a fact or piece of information invalidates an explanation or idea, it proves that it contains mistakes which make it unlikely to be true - used in scientific contexts:

children.name: làm mất hiệu lực
examples: ▪ None of the more recent views invalidates Hahnemann’s original discoveries or teachings.
▪ If we look closely at Professor Thomson’s argument, we see that his conclusion is invalidated by a number of factual errors.

children.name: demolish
children.definition: to prove that an argument or idea is completely wrong:

children.name: phá huỷ; đánh đổ
examples: ▪ It would not be difficult to demolish a theory that was so obviously a load of rubbish.
▪ There was a time when the response ‘that’s a value judgement’ would have demolished any argument in the educational field.

children.name: explode
examples: làm nổ, đập tan, làm tiêu tan (lý tưởng, ảo tưởng...)
explode a myth/rumour
đập tan một tin đồn/huyền thoại
to prove that something that many people think or believe is wrong or not true:
▪ The report explodes the myth that men are bed-hopping rogues.

children.name: negative
children.definition: a negative result of a medical or chemical test does not show any sign of the condition you are testing for and therefore proves it does not exist in this person or situation: không; phủ định, phủ nhận
examples: ▪ All the athletes’ drugs tests were negative.

children.name: ▪ a negative pregnancy test
examples: ▪ The first brain scan proved negative.

children.name: sth that proves sth is true
proof
children.definition: informationorfactsthat prove that something is true:
examples: bằng chứng
▪ He was the only person in the room when the money disappeared - what more proof do you want?
▪ The police knew she was guilty, but they had no proof.
proof of
bằng chứng của
▪ You can’t drink in bars without some proof of your age.
proof (that)
bằng chứng cho thấy
▪ There is no proof that he did it.
conclusive proofsomething that definitely proves something is true :chứng cớ thuyết phục
▪ It was alleged that he was stealing money from the till, but we never had any conclusive proof.

children.name: evidence
children.definition: informationthat helps to prove whether something is true or not:
examples: chứng cớ, bằng chứng
▪ The police did not have enough evidence to charge anybody with the murder.
evidence that
chứng cứ cho thấy
▪ There is some evidence that a small amount of alcohol is good for you.
evidence of/for
chứng cứ về
▪ evidence of life on other planets
medical/scientific/forensic etc evidence
bằng chứng y tế / khoa học / pháp y vv
▪ There is no scientific evidence to support this theory.
evidence to suggest/indicate/show etc something
bằng chứng để đề nghị/chỉ hiển thị một cái gì đó vv
▪ There is strong evidence to suggest that the Great Barrier Reef will have disappeared in 20 years time.
not a shred of evidenceno evidence at all : không một chút bằng chứng nào
▪ There is not a shred of evidence to support such a theory.

children.name: documentation
children.definition: official documents that are used to prove that a claim or statement is true or correct: tài liệu
examples: Can you produce documentation to support your claim?
As there is no formal documentation of your business partnership, it has no legal status.
Applicants must providesupporting documentation.

children.name: living proof
children.definition: a person, group, or place that proves that something is true or possible: bằng chứng sống

children.name: living proof of
examples: ▪ The team is living proof of the old saying that it’s not whom you play that counts, but when you play them.
▪ We know that English and French speakers can live together in Canada - Montreal is living proof of that.

children.name: living proof that
examples: ▪ Jordan is living proof that you don’t have to conform to the music industry’s standards in order to be accepted.

children.name: the acid test
children.definition: a way of finding out whether something is as good as people say it is, whether it works, or when it is true:
examples: ▪ The acid test of a good leader is the extent to which they select a style to suit the circumstances.

children.name: back up
children.definition: backsbupphrasal verb

children.name: to say that someone is telling the truth
examples: _Honestly, that's exactly what happened - Claire will back me up.
_Will you back meupif I say that I never saw him?
